template.template: Template App Skype for business Front-End role
template.name: Template App Skype for business Front-End role
template.description: This template assesses the status and overall health of services as well as the performance of the Front-End Skype for Business Server 2015. Note: You need to set thresholds for these counters according to your environment. It is recommended to monitor these counters for some period of time to understand potential value ranges and then set the thresholds accordingly. Portions of this documentation are based on: https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/gg398616.aspx.

item.name: IMMcu Conferences: Active Conferences
item.description: This component monitor returns the number of active conferences. You will need to baseline this counter by testing and monitoring the user load.

item.name: IMMcu Conferences: Connected Users
item.description: This component monitor returns the number of connected users in all conferences. You will need to baseline this counter by testing and monitoring the user load.

item.name: IMMcu Conferences: Throttled Sip Connections
item.key: perf_counter["\LS:ImMcu - IMMcu Conferences\IMMCU - Throttled Sip Connections"]
item.description: This component monitor returns the number of throttled Sip connections. If the value is greater than ten, it could indicate that Peer is not processing requests in a timely fashion. This can happen if the peer machine is overloaded. Peer is defined as the connected servers, adjacent Front-End servers, or MCUs in the same EE Pool. The same set of counters apply.

item.name: MCU Health And Performance: MCU Draining State
item.key: perf_counter["\LS:ImMcu - MCU Health And Performance\IMMCU - MCU Draining State"]
item.description: This component monitor returns the current draining status of the MCU. Possible values: 0 = Not requesting to drain. 1 = Requesting to drain. 2 = Draining. When a server is drained, it stops taking new connections and calls. These new connections and calls are routed through other servers in the pool. A server being drained allows its sessions on existing connections to continue until they naturally end. When all existing sessions have ended, the server is ready to be taken offline.

item.name: MCU Health And Performance: MCU Health State
item.key: perf_counter["\LS:ImMcu - MCU Health And Performance\IMMCU - MCU Health State"]
item.description: This component monitor returns the current health of the MCU. Possible values: 0 = Normal. 1 = Loaded. 2 = Full. 3 = Unavailable.

item.name: Load Management: Address space usage
item.key: perf_counter["\LS:SIP - Load Management\SIP - Address space usage"]
item.description: This component monitor returns the percentage of available address space currently in use by the server process. The returned value should be as low as possible.

item.name: Load Management: Average Holding Time For Incoming Messages
item.key: perf_counter["\LS:SIP - Load Management\SIP - Average Holding Time For Incoming Messages"]
item.description: This component monitor returns the average time that the server held the incoming messages currently being processed. This should usually be less than one second, on average, but it is normal to see short spikes of up to three seconds. The server will throttle new incoming messages after going above the high watermark and until the number of messages falls below the low watermark. The server starts rejecting new connections when the average holding time is greater than overload time of 15 seconds.

item.name: Load Management: Page file usage
item.key: perf_counter["\LS:SIP - Load Management\SIP - Page file usage"]
item.description: This component monitor returns the percentage of available page file space currently in use by the server process. The returned value should be as low as possible.

item.name: Peers: Average Flow-Control Delay
item.description: This component monitor returns the average delay, in seconds, in message processing when the socket is flow-controlled. You will need to baseline this counter by testing and monitoring the server's health. The returned value should be as low as possible.

item.name: Peers: Average Outgoing Queue Delay
item.key: perf_counter["\LS:SIP - Peers(_total)\SIP - Average Outgoing Queue Delay"]
item.description: This component monitor returns the average time, in seconds, that messages have been delayed in outgoing queues. Check the Outgoing Queue Delay for delays in sending messages to other servers or clients that could be causing messages to be accumulated in the server. The server will drop client connections if it is in a throttle state and messages stay in the outgoing queue for more than 32 seconds.

item.name: Peers: Connections Active
item.description: This component monitor returns the number of established connections that are currently active. A connection is considered established when peer credentials are verified (e.g. via MTLS), or the peer receives a 2xx response. You will need to baseline this counter by testing and monitoring the user load. This returned value should be less than 15,000 connections per Front-End.

item.name: Peers: Flow-controlled Connections
item.description: This component monitor returns the number of connections that are currently being flow-controlled (no socket receives are posted).

item.name: SIP - Incoming Requests /Sec
item.description: This component monitor returns the rate of received requests, per second. You will need to baseline this counter by testing and monitoring the user load.

item.name: SIP - Incoming Responses /Sec
item.description: This component monitor returns the rate of received responses, per second.

item.name: SIP - Outgoing Requests /Sec
item.description: This component monitor returns the rate of sent messages, per second.

item.name: SIP - Outgoing Responses /Sec
item.description: This component monitor returns the rate of outgoing responses, per second.

item.name: Peers: Sends Outstanding
item.description: This component monitor returns the number of messages that are currently present in the outgoing queues. If you receive error message 504, investigate the results from this counter. Doing so will indicate which servers are having problems. To do so, you will need to change the instance from _Total, to the server hostname. You can check this within perfmon.exe

item.name: Peers: TLS Connections Active
item.description: This component monitor returns the number of established TLS connections that are currently active. A TLS connection is considered established when the peer certificate, and possibly the host name, are verified for a trust relationship. You will need to baseline this counter by testing and monitoring the user load.

item.name: Protocol: Average Event Processing Time
item.key: perf_counter["\LS:SIP - Protocol\SIP - Average Event Processing Time"]
item.description: This component monitor returns the average time (in seconds) it takes to process a SIP transaction or dialog state change event.

item.name: Protocol: Average Incoming Message Processing Time
item.key: perf_counter["\LS:SIP - Protocol\SIP - Average Incoming Message Processing Time"]
item.description: This component monitor returns the average time (in seconds) it takes to process an incoming message.

item.name: Protocol: Average Local Message Processing Time
item.key: perf_counter["\LS:SIP - Protocol\SIP - Average Local Message Processing Time"]
item.description: This component monitor returns the average time (in seconds) it takes to process a locally generated message.

item.name: Protocol: Average Number Of Active Worker Threads
item.key: perf_counter["\LS:SIP - Protocol\SIP - Average Number Of Active Worker Threads"]
item.description: This component monitor returns the average number of active SIP worker threads that process incoming messages.

item.name: Protocol: Events In Processing
item.description: This component monitor returns the number of SIP transactions, or dialog state change events, that are currently being processed. You will need to baseline this counter by testing and monitoring the user load.

item.name: SIP - Events Processed /Sec
item.description: This component monitor returns the rate of SIP transaction or dialog state change events that were delivered for processing, per second.

item.name: SIP - Incoming Messages /Sec
item.description: This component monitor returns the rate of received messages, per second. You will need to baseline this counter by testing and monitoring the user load.

item.name: Protocol: Messages In Server
item.description: This component monitor returns the number of messages currently being processed by the server.

item.name: SIP - Outgoing Messages /Sec
item.description: This component monitor returns the rate of sent messages, per second.

item.name: SIP - Local 500 Responses /Sec
item.description: This component monitor returns the rate of 500 responses generated by the server, per second. This can indicate that there is a server component that is not functioning correctly.

item.name: SIP - Local 503 Responses /Sec
item.description: This component monitor returns the rate of 503 responses generated by the server, per second. The 503 code corresponds to the server being unavailable. On a healthy server, you should not receive this code at a steady rate. However, during ramp up, after a server has been brought back online, there may be some 503 responses. Once all users get back in and the server returns to a stable state, there should no longer be any 503 responses returned.

item.name: SIP - Local 504 Responses /Sec
item.description: This component monitor returns the rate of 504 responses generated by the server, per second. A few 504 responses to clients (for clients disconnecting abruptly) is to be expected, but this counter mainly indicates connectivity issues with other servers. It can indicate connection failures or delays connecting to.

item.name: USrv - DBStore: Queue Latency (msec)
item.description: This component monitor returns the average time, in milliseconds, that a request is held in the database queue. This counter represents the time that a request spends in the queue of the Back-End Database Server. If the topology is healthy, this counter averages less than 100 ms. Occasional spikes are acceptable. The value will be higher on Front-End Servers that are located at the site opposite the location of the Back-End Database Servers. This value can increase if the Back-End Database Server is having performance problems or if network latency is too high. If the returned value is high, check both network latency and the health of the Back-End Database Server. Server health decreases as latency increases to 12 seconds, when server throttling begins.

item.name: USrv - DBStore: Sproc Latency (msec)
item.description: This component monitor returns the average time, in milliseconds, it takes to execute a stored procedure call. A healthy state is considered to be less than 100 ms. Server health decreases as latency increases to 12 seconds, when server throttling begins.

item.name: USrv - Https Transport: Active HTTPS connections
item.key: perf_counter["\LS:USrv - Https Transport\USrv - Active HTTPS connections"]
item.description: This component monitor returns the number of active HTTPS connections

item.name: USrv - Https Transport: Number of failed connection attempts /Sec
item.key: perf_counter["\LS:USrv - Https Transport\USrv - Number of failed connection attempts / Sec"]
item.description: This component monitor returns the rate of connection attempt failures, per second. You will need to baseline this counter by testing and monitoring the server's health.

item.name: Serivce: Lync Server File Transfer Agent
Service: Lync Server Master Replicator Agent
Serivce: Lync Server Replica Replicator Agent

trigger.expression: {Template App Skype for business Front-End role:perf_counter["\LS:SIP - Protocol\SIP - Average Incoming Message Processing Time"].last()}>1
trigger.name: Lync average incoming message processing time too high

trigger.expression: {Template App Skype for business Front-End role:perf_counter["\LS:ImMcu - MCU Health And Performance\IMMCU - MCU Health State"].last()}<>0
trigger.name: Lync MCU Health State not in normal state

trigger.expression: {Template App Skype for business Front-End role:perf_counter["\LS:USrv - Https Transport\USrv - Number of failed connection attempts / Sec"].last()}>1
trigger.name: Lync number of failed connection attempts too high

trigger.expression: {Template App Skype for business Front-End role:perf_counter["\LS:USrv - DBStore\USrv - Queue Latency (msec)"].last()}>100
trigger.name: Lync queue latency too high

trigger.expression: {Template App Skype for business Front-End role:service.info["Lync Server Application Sharing",state].last()}<>0
trigger.name: Lync Server Application Sharing service stopped

trigger.expression: {Template App Skype for business Front-End role:service.info["Lync Server Audio/Video Conferencing",state].last()}<>0
trigger.name: Lync Server Audio/Video Conferencing service stopped

trigger.expression: {Template App Skype for business Front-End role:service.info["Lync Server File Transfer Agent",state].last()}<>0
trigger.name: Lync Server File Transfer Agent service stopped

trigger.expression: {Template App Skype for business Front-End role:service.info["Lync Server Front-End",state].last()}<>0
trigger.name: Lync Server Front-End service stopped

trigger.expression: {Template App Skype for business Front-End role:service.info["Lync Server IM Conferencing",state].last()}<>0
trigger.name: Lync Server IM Conferencing service stopped

trigger.expression: {Template App Skype for business Front-End role:service.info["Lync Server Master Replicator Agent",state].last()}<>0
trigger.name: Lync Server Master Replicator Agent service stopped

trigger.expression: {Template App Skype for business Front-End role:service.info["Lync Server Replica Replicator Agent",state].last()}<>0
trigger.name: Lync Server Replica Replicator Agent service stopped

trigger.expression: {Template App Skype for business Front-End role:perf_counter["\LS:USrv - DBStore\USrv - Sproc Latency (msec)"].last()}>100
trigger.name: Lync sproc latency is too high

trigger.expression: {Template App Skype for business Front-End role:perf_counter["\LS:ImMcu - IMMcu Conferences\IMMCU - Throttled Sip Connections"].last()}<>0
trigger.name: Lync throttle sip connections
